    Introduction Load Data Merge & subset

Subset and merge

2024-02-21

subset_and_merge.Rmd
library(pixelatorR)
library(SeuratObject)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(glue)
options(pixelatorR.arrow_outdir = tempdir())

To demonstrate how subset and merging works in pixelatorR, let’s load our example data set.

dir.create("PBMC_data")
download.file(url = "https://pixelgen-technologies-datasets.s3.eu-north-1.amazonaws.com/mpx-datasets/pixelator/0.12.0/1k-human-pbmcs-v1.0-immunology-I/Sample01_human_pbmcs_unstimulated.dataset.pxl?download=1",
              destfile = "PBMC_data/Sample01_human_pbmcs_unstimulated.dataset.pxl")
pxl_file <- "PBMC_data/Sample01_human_pbmcs_unstimulated.dataset.pxl"
seur_obj <- ReadMPX_Seurat(pxl_file)
## ✔ Created a 'Seurat' object with 477 cells and 80 targeted surface proteins

merge CellGraphAssays

First, we’ll take a look at how we can merge CellGraphAssays. We can extract the CellGraphAssay object as follows:

cg_assay <- seur_obj[["mpxCells"]]

When merging multiple CellGraphAssays, a prefix is added to each sample:

cg_assay_merged <- merge(cg_assay, 
                         list(cg_assay, cg_assay))
glue("First 3 component names: \n",
     "{paste(head(colnames(cg_assay_merged), 3), collapse=', ')}")
## First 3 component names: 
## Sample1_RCVCMP0000000, Sample1_RCVCMP0000002, Sample1_RCVCMP0000003
glue("Last 3 component names: \n",
     "{paste(tail(colnames(cg_assay_merged), 3), collapse=', ')}")
## Last 3 component names: 
## Sample3_RCVCMP0003679, Sample3_RCVCMP0005679, Sample3_RCVCMP0006318

You can also pass add.cell.ids to use custom prefixes:

cg_assay_merged <- merge(cg_assay, 
                         list(cg_assay, cg_assay), 
                         add.cell.ids = c("A", "B", "C"))
glue("First 3 component names: \n",
     "{paste(head(colnames(cg_assay_merged), 3), collapse=', ')}")
## First 3 component names: 
## A_RCVCMP0000000, A_RCVCMP0000002, A_RCVCMP0000003
glue("Last 3 component names: \n",
     "{paste(tail(colnames(cg_assay_merged), 3), collapse=', ')}")
## Last 3 component names: 
## C_RCVCMP0003679, C_RCVCMP0005679, C_RCVCMP0006318

When we merge the three data sets, the edge list files are copied into a new directory and each sample gets it’s own sub directory:

ArrowDir(cg_assay_merged) %>% 
  fs::dir_tree()
## /private/var/folders/gw/bdcqhnvs0m9gs_mq8n51jtbc0000gn/T/RtmpRaXvfR/nPKfB-2024-02-22-093555
## ├── sample=A
## │   └── edgelist.parquet
## ├── sample=B
## │   └── edgelist.parquet
## └── sample=C
##     └── edgelist.parquet

pixelatorR is strict about the naming of cells/components. It only accepts a prefix followed by a PXL id. The reason is that the prefixes are used by some functions (s.a. LoadCellGraphs) to know in what sample sub directories to fetch data from.

If the renaming of cells/components is invalid, an error is raised:

cg_assay_renamed <- RenameCells(cg_assay, 
                                new.names = paste0("A", colnames(cg_assay)))
## <error/rlang_error>
## Error in `RenameCells()`:
## ! Failed to merge CellGraphAssays.
## 
## Make sure to follow these steps:
## 
## 1. CellGraphAssay column names should have the following format:
##    ^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9]*_RCVCMP\d7$
##    where the first part is a sample ID and the second part is the PXL ID, 
##    separated by an underscore. For example, Sample1_RCVCMP0000000.
## 
## 2. When merging Seurat objects, make sure to set add.cell.ids.
## 
## 3. Cannot merge Seurat objects with CellGraphAssays twice due to naming conflicts. 
##    Instead, merge all data sets once:
##    se_merged <- merge(se1, list(se2, se3, se4, ...))
##    Attempting to merge the merged object again will fail:
##    se_double_merged <- merge(se_merged, se_merged)
## ---
## Backtrace:
##     ▆
##  1. ├─base::tryCatch(...)
##  2. │ └─base (local) tryCatchList(expr, classes, parentenv, handlers)
##  3. │   ├─base (local) tryCatchOne(...)
##  4. │   │ └─base (local) doTryCatch(return(expr), name, parentenv, handler)
##  5. │   └─base (local) tryCatchList(expr, names[-nh], parentenv, handlers[-nh])
##  6. │     └─base (local) tryCatchOne(expr, names, parentenv, handlers[[1L]])
##  7. │       └─base (local) doTryCatch(return(expr), name, parentenv, handler)
##  8. ├─SeuratObject::RenameCells(cg_assay, new.names = paste0("A", colnames(cg_assay)))
##  9. └─pixelatorR:::RenameCells.CellGraphAssay(cg_assay, new.names = paste0("A", colnames(cg_assay)))

The error message gives us a solution. We are missing an underscore between the prefix and the PXL ids. The following renaming is valid:

cg_assay_renamed <- RenameCells(cg_assay, 
                                new.names = paste0("A_", colnames(cg_assay)))

merge Seurat objects with CellGraphAssays

The strict naming is necessary to handle merging of CellGraphAssays, but can create issues when merging Seurat objects. If the Seurat objects contain CellGraphAssays, we need to set add.cell.ids. The following is valid:

seur_obj_merged <- merge(seur_obj, list(seur_obj, seur_obj), 
                         add.cell.ids = c("Sample1", "Sample2", "Sample3"))

But the following is not valid:

# DO NOT RUN
seur_obj_merged <- merge(seur_obj, 
                         list(seur_obj, seur_obj))

Another issue is that the stricter naming prevents us from merging already merged objects. For instance, the following doesn’t work:

# DO NOT RUN
seur_obj_merged_twice <- merge(seur_obj_merged, 
                               seur_obj_merged, 
                               add.cell.ids = c("Batch1", "Batch2"))

Instead, make sure to merge all samples with a single merge operation.

subset CellGraphAssays or Seurat objects with CellGraphAssays

When subsetting CellGraphAssays or Seurat objects containing CellGraphAssays, the edge lists are loaded filtered to exclude components which do not pass the filter. To avoid overwriting the edge list files associated with the input object, a new directory is created:

seur_obj_subset <- subset(seur_obj, 
                          cells = colnames(seur_obj)[1:10])

And we see that the edge list directory associated with seur_obj_subset is a new directory.

ArrowDir(seur_obj_subset) %>% 
  fs::dir_tree()
## /private/var/folders/gw/bdcqhnvs0m9gs_mq8n51jtbc0000gn/T/RtmpRaXvfR/U3C0x-2024-02-22-093558
## └── sample=S1
##     └── edgelist.parquet

Since each edge list file has to be filtered each time subset is called, subsetting can become slow. For complex filters, it can be useful to pass a set of components/cells to keep instead of filtering by meta data columns. For instance, the following code will remove components with less than 1,000 edges or more than 30,000 edges:

system.time({
  
seur_obj_subset <- seur_obj %>% 
  subset(edges >= 1e3) %>% 
  subset(edges <= 3e4)

})
##    user  system elapsed 
##   7.873   0.950   5.256

But this alternative will be faster:

system.time({
  
components_keep <- colnames(seur_obj)[between(seur_obj$edges, 
                                              left = 1e3, 
                                              right = 3e4)]
seur_obj_subset <- seur_obj %>% 
  subset(cells = components_keep)

})
##    user  system elapsed 
##   3.776   0.494   2.487
